ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned a lot more theory about econometrics. Felt more applied and useful than 117 since we had the basics out of the way and could look at a variety of research papers.
sadly, very little.
Data Analysis, Econometrics
Probability rules, asymptotic inference, bootstrap, randomization inference, interpreting regression results. More theory that's less intuitive than ECON117. More advanced R coding.
Very boring, but teaches you a bunch about R and econometrics.
R skills
I learned valuable practical econometrics skills that were not covered in previous theoretical courses.
Data analysis
I learned a lot about how to conduct economic/econometric research.
Econometric theory, R coding, etc.
I learned a very rigorous set of skills for data analysis that have been core to my research.
Statistical analysis skills and theories, various methods to implement these skills in R.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: interesting material, Professor cared about students

Weaknesses: one of the most disorganized professors I have ever had. I felt like we could have covered so much more content if the class had been better planned out and he was able to answer questions more concisely or direct people to other resources. There were multiple times every class period during which I would zone out because professor was going down a rabbit hole answering questions for other students that were not super relevant.

absolutely terrible. very unclear lectures, unclear office hours, unclear questions, unclear guidelines, unclear problem sets

please make lectures recorded
Good amount of work, problem sets and quizzes were not overbearing, responsive professor/TAs

Strenghts: I thought the psets were generally well-designed. They gave me an opportunity to practice more advanced R coding and I liked that they were based on published research. The slides and handouts were also great and super clear.
Weaknesses: the class is a lot more work than I imagined with 6 psets, 6 quizzes, midterm, final, and an empirical project. We were promised alternating psets/quizzes each week but for the first half of the semester there would be a pset AND a quiz almost every week. I also feel like the instructions for the empirical project were too broad for us to actually learn much from it. At this stage of learning and with a tight time/word limit, I would've preferred a more narrowly defined project that allowed us to focus more on econometrics methods rather than finding and cleaning data. It was also sometimes unclear how the section materials related to the lectures, but the actual section content was super well-explained. Some questions on Ed were also left unanswered.
Very boring, and pretty uninteresting material. Taught in a structured manner with labs though.

Strengths: Problem sets, quizzes and exams are fair and follow the material we learn in class. Class content draws from real papers so that we can see the real world applications of the methods we learn. 

Weaknesses: Lectures sometimes feel unclear and too dense with notation. Lectures also move fast and are not always comprehensive. I would've preferred that new concepts were introduced via the whiteboard so that it's easier to follow.
Good problem sets, but the lectures are pretty dry
Strengths - good TA Weaknesses - very hard to follow because of the structure of the class
The instructor was excellent and did a great job of walking us through each topic using examples. The course can be dry at times, but is relatively easy to follow and it is well-taught.
Content is very fast; could have more interactive assessments.

I personally found the class very hard to follow. The content was all over the place, and the lack of textbook or supported readings meant that if we were confused there weren't many other resources to turn to for information. While I appreciated the labs and the example studies used to support the learning, I wish we went through some of the more theoretical content more slowly, as I feel like we glanced over some of the most important content very quickly.

Strengths: psets are good practice for the material, the number of assignments (psets and quizzes) meant it is hard to get behind, the applications in R were helpful for visualizing material that is sometimes quite theoretical

Weaknesses: the second half of the course didn't seem as organized and got a lot more theoretical than the first half, so more applications and demonstrations would have been helpful to see how these things actually work; sometimes the prof's explanations of the more theoretical side sort of went down a rabbit hole of statistical notation and were difficult to follow. the number of assignments was at times a bit overwhelming, but generally manageable.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you are interested in econometrics then yes! I would assume you're only taking it to write a thesis or because you have genuine interest in econometrics. If you are willing to put in the work, I found the material to be very interesting and it gave me a lot of insight into using econometrics that I felt was shoved into the final 2 weeks of 117.
Absolutely not. I can't believe this is a requirement for the Econ thesis. Very poorly designed, very poorly laid out

No, I do not recommend this course, especially if you want to learn actual econometrics. I highly suggest you take courses in the Statistics department first, as they are better facilitated towards student learning of stats methods, coding, and the math required.
Gives a good insight into econometrics, further than ECON 117
Yes for learning more R coding and more advanced econometrics theory, but it's sometimes hard to see how all the math/theories are actually useful/applicable.
Not really, unless you want to write your thesis.

It depends. I would recommend this course to economics majors. The class provides a deeper dive into the econometrics concepts learned from 117, and the end-of-semester project was a good way to apply the econometrics methods taught in the class. The material is useful for anyone interested in economics research and more quantitative work in economics. I would also recommend this class to students who want to gain more experience in R.
Take it if you have to, otherwise S&DS courses are probably more engaging
I would definitely recommend this course to any student hoping to do further empirical work in the social sciences.
Only if you have to take it for the major
Take it if you need it for the Econ major, or if you want to challenge yourself to actually leave Yale knowing how to do economics research.
If you need to take the class, yes. If not, it is a little dense for an elective course.

If you're interested in stats, the first half of the course will be interesting to you. If you're interested in the more theoretical parts with fewer applications in R, then the second half will also be interesting to you. I personally enjoyed the course up to around midterm when it got a bit too theoretical for me with fewer applications.
